User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the AI Excuse Generator application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

plan.description: Subscription plan of the user (FREE or PREMIUM).

dailyUsage.description: Number of excuses generated by the user today.

lastUsageDate.description: The last date the user generated an excuse.

createdAt.description: Timestamp indicating when the user account was created.

definition.description: Stores user details. The document ID is the userId, enabling path-based ownership. Includes fields like email, plan, dailyUsage, lastUsageDate and createdAt. All data for a user is self-contained, enabling Authorization Independence.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user, matching the Firebase Authentication UID.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to facilitate secure user authentication and data management for the AI Excuse Generator application.  It prioritizes Authorization Independence by avoiding `get()` calls in security rules and enabling atomic operations. The core entity is the `User`, and the structure revolves around it. Specifically, user data is stored in a collection named `users`, with each document ID being the `userId`. This adheres to the Path-Based Ownership access model.

**Authorization Independence:**  Authorization independence is achieved because the `users/{userId}` documents contain all relevant information for access control. Rules can directly check `request.auth.uid == userId` to verify ownership without needing to `get()` any other documents. All data relevant to the user is contained within their document, ensuring that operations on user-owned data do not depend on external data.

**QAPs Support:** The structure supports secure list operations because all documents in the `users` collection have the same security posture (i.e., only the authenticated user can access their document). The `list` operation can be secured by enforcing `request.auth.uid == resource.id` in the rules, preventing unauthorized access to other user documents.

The decision to store the `plan` field directly within the `users` document simplifies the process of checking user subscription status during excuse generation. This design ensures that the system can efficiently verify a user's eligibility for premium features.
